title: Dr. Edith Irby Jones, Riverside General Hospital
description: Dr. Edith Mae Irby Jones was the first African American student accepted to the University of Arkansas Medical School (UAMS), the first African American accepted to any all-White medical school in the South, and the first woman president of the National Medical Association.

title: Lena Lowe Jordan
description: Lena Lowe Jordan was an African-American registered nurse and hospital administrator who managed two institutions for African Americans, a hospital for the care of crippled children, which later became a general hospital. In addition, she began a unique training program for young black women who wanted to become practical nurses.

title: Mamie Odessa Hale Garland
description: Mamie Odessa Hale Garland served as midwife consultant for the Arkansas Department of Health from 1945 to 1950 and is credited with training the states midwives to ensure that they knew the proper techniques to manage the medical aspects of pregnancy. Her contributions led to establishing improved maternal/infant mortality rates and regulation of midwives in Arkansas.

title: Florence Char
description: Florence Char was born in Peking, China on April 7, 1923. By the early 1940s, her parents sent Florence and her brother to live in the western United States. Dr. Char earned her medical degree at the State University of New York Health Science Center in Brooklyn in 1952. She interned in Pediatrics at the University of Minnesota Hospitals from 1952-53 and was a fellow in Pediatric Cardiology in 1955-1957. She was certified in Pediatrics in 1959 and Pediatric Cardiology in 1965. She joined the faculty at the University of Arkansas School of Medicine in 1963. In 1971, Dr. Char established the first genetics clinics and cytogenetics laboratory in Arkansas and was instrumental in the creation of the Arkansas Genetics Program at UAMS. In 1978, Dr. Char described a genetic birth defect that came to be called Char syndrome. She retired in 1990 with the rank of professor emeritus.
institutions: Arkansas Children's Hospital; Johns Hopkins University, Peking University; State University of New York; University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences
subject: Cytogenetics; Genetics; Genetics, Medicine; Pediatric cardiology; Pediatrics

title: M. Joycelyn Elders
description: A graduate of Philander Smith College and 1960 graduate of UAMS, Dr. Elders (1933-) taught pediatrics at UAMS from 1967 until 1987. In 1987, she was appointed by Gov. Bill Clinton to be the first African American and the first female Director of the Arkansas Department of Health. In September 1993, President Clinton appointed her the first African American woman to be Surgeon General of the Public Health Service. Resigning from that position in December 1994, Dr. Elders returned to UAMS as a professor of pediatrics. Dr. Elders was inducted into the College of Medicine's Hall of Fame in 2004
institutions: Arkansas Children's Hospital; Arkansas Department of Health; Army Medical Specialist Corp; Brooke Army Medical Center; Fitzsimmons Hospital; Letterman Army Hospital; Philander Smith College; University of Arkansas Medical Center; University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences; University of Minnesota Hospital

title: Dr. Patricia A. Newton, Psychiatry
description: Patricia A. Newton, M.D., M.H.P., M.A. was born in Tuckerman, Arkansas. She was the medical director, a former president, and founding member of the Black Psychiatrists of America (BPA). She was one of the first APA/NIMH Fellows and the first woman chair of the Department of Psychiatry at Provident Hospital in Baltimore. Dr. Newton also served as academic faculty at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine for over sixteen years.  Her clinical work centered on anxiety disorders with a special focus on posttraumatic stress disorder, as well as depression and chronic mental illness.  Dr. Newton was renowned for her pioneering work integrating African spirituality into Black mental health and for working with health care professionals in Africa and the Caribbean as well as in the United States.
institutions: Black Psychiatrists of America;  Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health; University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences; University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff; Washington University School of Medicine
subject: Mental Health; Public Health; Psychiatrist; Psychiatry

title: Lidia Gertrudis Sogandares, UAMS
description: Lidia Gertrudis Sogandares was the first Latin American graduate of the UAMS College of Medicine. A citizen of the Republic of Panama, she entered the University of Arkansas School of Medicine completing the undergraduate program in 1932 and graduating in 1934. She interned at the Women's Hospital in Philadelphia, PA specializing in the fields of Obstetrics and Gynecology. After returning to her native country, Dr. Sogandares joined the medical staff at St. Thomas Hospital in Panama City and gradually rose to the position of Chief of Obstetrics and Gynecology. The successful completion of her education and entrance into medical practice was widely regarded as a great accomplishment for the Women's Rights Movement. Dr. Sogandares was heralded as the first female doctor in Panama and Central America. At the time of her death, she was honored as a co-founder and first female member of the Panamanian Academy of Medicine and Surgery; She was a co-founder and the first president of the Panamanian Society of Obstetrics and Gynecology, a member of the Pan-American Alliance of Medical Women, the Isthmian Medical Association of the Canal Zone, and the Women Medical Association.
institutions: Gorgas Memorial Institute; National Medical Association; Panamanian Academy of Medicine and Surgery; Panamanian Red Cross; Panamamian Society of Obstetrics and Gynecology; Santo Tomas Hospital (Panama); University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences; University of Panama School of Medicine; Women's Hospital, Philadelpha

title: Bennie "Mama" McGuire, on a midwife appointment
description: Bennie "Mama" McGurie grew up on a farm in Hardemann County, TN. Inspired by her grandmother who had been a midwife, she learned midwife techniques from a rural doctor. Bennie McGurie moved to Marked Tree, Arkansas in 1914. She was to deliver over a thousand babies during her lifetime. When asked about her patients, Bennie reflected,"Most of the ones I went to were broke and in trouble--they couldn't afford to pay $300 to have thier babies born in a hospital. I couldn't turn my back on them. I swore an oath when I became a midwife that I'd help the ones that needed it, and that's what I done."

title: Sophronia Reacie Williams at her church
description: Sophronia Reacie Williams worked as a nurse and nurse educator for forty-six years specializing in mental health. In 1979, Williams joined UAMS College of Nursing where she worked with both adult and child mental health patients. In 1994, she retired from UAMS as an associate professor. Reflecting on her impactful career, Williams observed "I really cared. I do a lot of giving of myself to people. I did show I cared about them, treating them as human beings." Over the course of her career in medicine, Sophronia Williams was among the first African-American nurses to integrate hospitals in Missouri, Ohio, and Colorado.
creator: Aprille Hanson
institutions: Case Western Reserve University at Frances Payne Bolton; College of Nursing at the University of Colorado in Denver; Homer G. title: Group portrait of African-American Midwives in Forrest City, Arkansas
description: The Arkansas Board of Health took this group portrait of black midwives in Forrest City in 1929. Midwives are women specially trained to assist women in childbirth and were often called upon to deliver the baby in place of a doctor. A midwife was very knowledgeable about childbirth and the uses of medical herbs. Traditionally, Arkansas midwives learned their trade from another practicing midwife, quite often a family member. After the birth, a midwife took care of the newborn and attended to the recovery of the new mother. In the 1920s, under the Sheppard-Towner program, the Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) issued permits to midwives who attended classes and were required to pass exams to practice midwifery. Midwives remain today vital care givers in a community.
creator: Arkansas Board of Health
institutions: Arkansas Department of Health
subject: Midwives; Midwifery; Public Health
location: Forrest City, AR (St. Francis County)

title: Suzanne Burton, Home Care Professional
description: Suzanne Burton of Morrilton, Arkansas was impactful in contributing to the practice of Home Care throughout central Arkansas. The pupose of Home Care is to enable chronically ill patients to remain at home with their families while still receiving medical and nursing assistance. As a Home Care nurse, Suzanne Burton provided care and comfort to her patients as well as thier loved ones. Regarding her profession, she said "I love my work. The people on our staff provide important care to thier patients at a time when it is truely needed; in return when we come to visit we feel appreciated. It's as if we are an extended family."
institutions: Arkansas Baptist Hospital; Conway County Hospital; St. Anthony's Hospital; University of Central Arkansas; Visiting Nurse Association of Arkansas

title: Charolette Tidwell, founder of Antioch Youth and Family
description: Charlotte Tidwell is a longtime resident of Fort Smith, Arkansas. In 1965, Charlotte began her studies in nursing and became the first black woman to complete the nursing program at Sparks Hospital. For over thirty years she servered her community as a nurse and hospital administrator. Upon retirement, Charlotte Tidwell founded the non-profit Antioch Youth and Family. Her organization distributes nutrituous food to needing families throughout Western Arkansas and Eastern Oklahoma and has grown to be the largest food pantry throughout the region. While retired, Tidwell considers that she is still following her calling as a nurse by addressing food insecurity in the community. She says,"The work has nothing to do with Charlotte. It's not about me. It has everything to do with knitting back communities to be whole."
creator: Joel Culberson, Photographer
institutions: Antioch Youth and Family; St. Edward Mercy Hospital; Sparks Regional Medical Center
subject: Health Facility Administrators; Nurses; Philanthropist
location: Fort Smith, AR (Sebastian County)

title: Barbara Johnson, UAMS Med Tech
description: Barbara Johnson was born in Hot Springs, Arkansas. She received her B.S. in Nursing in 1955 from the Meharry Medical College, School of Nursing in Nashville, TN. In 1972, she graduated from the University of Central Arkansas with a M.S. in Education and a M.S. in Nursing. She began her nursing career at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences. From 1960-1965, Barbara Johnson became the first black woman to hold the position of Operating Room head nurse. In 1966, she became the Director of Medical Services for the OEO Headstart program, and afterward joined the nursing staff of the Veterans Administration Hospital. In 1975, Governor Dale Bumpers appointed Barbara Johnson as head of the Arkansas State Board of Health of which she was the first African-American woman to become president of that organization. In 1980, she was an active member of the Little Rock Black Nurses Association and served as Corresponding Secretary. From 1991-2014 she was a Continuing Education Consultant for the Arkansas State Nurses Association, Individual Educational Activity Program. Barbara Johnson is an ARNA Hall of Fame Inductee.
institutions: Arkansas State Health Department; Veteran's Administration Hospital; Meharry Medical College's School of Nursing; University of Central Arkansas; University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences
subject: Nurses; Public Health; Public Health Administration
location: Hot Springs, AR (Garland County); Little Rock, AR (Pulaski County);

filename: Arkansas Midwives Deshae County Dumas AR 1-26-1928.jpg
title: Training of Arkansas Midwives in Dumas, AR
description: The Arkansas Department of Health performing a midwives training sesssion in Dumas, Arkansas in 1928. Midwives are women specially trained to assist women in childbirth and were often called upon to deliver the baby in place of a doctor. A midwife was very knowledgeable about childbirth and the uses of medical herbs. Traditionally, Arkansas midwives learned their trade from another practicing midwife, quite often a family member. After the birth, a midwife took care of the newborn and attended to the recovery of the new mother. In the 1920s, under the Sheppard-Towner program, the Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) issued permits to midwives who attended classes and were required to pass exams to practice midwifery. Midwives remain today vital care givers in a community.
institutions: Arkansas Department of Health
subject: Midwifery; Midwives; Public Health
location: Dumas, AR (Desha County)

title: Woman in United States Cadet Nurse Corps uniform sitting in garden, Rohwer, Arkansas, September 23, 1944
description: Following the attack on Pearly Harbor on December 7, 1941, President Franklin Roosevelt established the War Relocation Authority (WRA) for the relocation, maintenance, and supervision of the Japanese American population. According to registration records, of the 120,000 Japanese Americans interned into the camps some 130 were registered nurses and 70 were registered midwives. In this photograph, a woman in United States Cadet Nurse Corps uniform sits in a garden at the Rohwer Relocation Camp.
creator: Muramoto, Walter
institutions: US Army Nursing Corps
subject: Japanese American--Evacuation and relocation, 1942-1945; Nurses; Rohwer Relocation Center (Ark.)
location: Rohwer, AR (Desha County)

title: Maud Hines in Red Cross uniform, 1918
description: At the outset of World War I, African-American women sought inclusion in the US Army Nurse Corps to serve in the war effort. Some did so due to patriotic fervor while others wished to demonstrate that were loyal Americans who deserved the full benefits of citizenship. They faced exceptional barriers due to societal views on sex and race. It was not until July 1918 that African-American women were included as reserve nurses in the American Red Cross. They were allowed to contribute strictly as reserve in case of emergency. That crisis occurred in October 1918 with the outbreak of the Spanish Influenza. In the face of pandemic, black nurses were badly needed to tend to the sick. Maud Hines was one such nurse who was deployed to combat the viral outbreak at Camp Pike in Little Rock, Arkansas.
institutions: American Red Cross
subject: Camp Pike (Ark.); Nurses; Public Health; Spanish Influenza Epidemic, 1918-1919

title: Stories from the Archives (Episode 2): Mamie O. Hale, R.N.
description: Mamie Odessa Hale Garland served as midwife consultant for the Arkansas Department of Health from 1945 to 1950 and is credited with training the states midwives to ensure that they knew the proper techniques to manage the medical aspects of pregnancy. Her contributions led to establishing improved maternal/infant mortality rates and regulation of midwives in Arkansas.

title: Dr. Fortunata L. Mendoza, UAMS
description: Dr. Fortunata L. Mendoza, MD, FAAD is a certified Dermatologist with more than twenty-five years of experience. She received her Medical Degree, Cum Laude, at the prestigious Santo Tomas University, Philippines. She then completed a Medicine Internship and Dermatology Residency at Emory University School of Medicine in Atlanta, GA.  Moving to Arkansas, Dr. Mendoza then taught Dermatology at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences in Little Rock, AR where she was also Chief of Dermatology of the Veterans Administration Medical Center and Acting Chairman of the Dermatology Department at the university. Dr. Mendoza is a Fellow of the American Academy of Dermatology. She is a member of the Los Angeles Metro Dermatology Society and the Womens Dermatology Society.  She has written various articles related to Dermatology and has given numerous lectures abroad.
institutions: Emory University School of Medicine (GA); Gateway Medical Spa (CA); University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences; University of Santo Tomas (Philippines)
subject: Dermatologists; Dermatology; Physicians
location: Little Rock, AR (Pulaski County); Mira Loma, CA; Republic of the Philippines

title: Tereisita L. Angtuaco, M.D.
description: Dr. Teresita L. Angtuaco is a Professor of Radiology, Obstetrics and Gynecology in the College of Medicine. She is also a Professor of Imaging and Radiation Sciences in the College of Health Professions and Professor of Health Policy and Management in the College of Public Health. Although she came to UAMS in 1979 as a nuclear medicine resident she developed special interest in Ultrasound. She became chief of Ultrasound in 1981 and the Director of the Division of Body Imaging in 2011. She is the medical director of the School of Diagnostic Medical Sonography in the College of Health Professions. Her main area of interest is ultrasound prenatal diagnosis. She established the first obstetric ultrasound service in Arkansas in 1982. In 2017, she received the Alice Ettinger Lifetime Achievement Award from the AAWR. In addition to her local teaching duties, she has lectured on a variety of ultrasound topics in 25 states and 8 countries.
institutions: Central Arkansas Veterans Healthcare System, Little Rock; Lahey Clinic (Boston, MA); Radiological Society of North America (RSNA); ST Barnabus Medical Center; University of Arkansas Medical Center; University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences; University of the Philippines College of Medicine (Manila)
subject: Diagnostic Imaging; Gynecology; Nuclear Medicine; Obstetrics; Physicians; Radiology; Radiography, Abdominal; Ultrasonography
location: Little Rock, AR (Pulaski County); Republic of the Philippines

title: Dr. Carmelita S. Pablo, UAMS
description: Dr. Carmelita Pablo joined the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences in 1981, serving as chair of the Department of Anesthesiology from 2002 until her retirement. She served as interim chair of the department in 2001, and was an associate professor in the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery in the College of Medicine. She taught more than 1,000 residents during her thirty-one years at UAMS. Dr. Pablo received her medical degree in 1968 from the University of Santo Tomas. At Temple University Hospital in Philadelphia, she completed her residency, followed by an anesthesiology fellowship at UAMS. She has been included in the list of Arkansas Best Doctors as named by Best Doctors Inc.
institutions: Temple University Hospital (PA); University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences; University of Santo Tomas (Philippines)
subject: Anesthesiology; Orthopaedics; Physicians
location: Little Rock, AR (Pulaski County); Manila (Philippines)

title: Dr. Patricia A. Newton, HAPI
description: Patricia A. Newton, M.D., M.H.P., M.A. was born in Tuckerman, Arkansas. She was the medical director, a former president, and founding member of the Black Psychiatrists of America (BPA). She was one of the first APA/NIMH Fellows and the first woman chair of the Department of Psychiatry at Provident Hospital in Baltimore. Dr. Newton also served as academic faculty at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine for over sixteen years.  Her clinical work centered on anxiety disorders with a special focus on posttraumatic stress disorder, as well as depression and chronic mental illness.  Dr. Newton was renowned for her pioneering work integrating African spirituality into Black mental health and for working with health care professionals in Africa and the Caribbean as well as in the United States.
institutions: Black Psychiatrists of America;  Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health; University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences; University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff; Washington University School of Medicine
subject: Mental Health; Public Health; Psychiatrist; Psychiatry
location: Ghana (West Africa); Pine Bluff, AR (Jefferson County); Tuckerman, AR (Jackson County); St. Louis, MO; Baltimore, MD
